subject: Science
question: Soil is made from:

subject: Science
question: Soil is made from: A) plants growing in the ground B) rocks breaking down over time C) minerals melting together D) animals digging holes
explanation: Soil is formed when rocks are broken down by weather, wind, and water over many years. This process is called weathering.

subject: Science
question: Soil is made from: A) rocks breaking down over time B) plants growing in the ground C) minerals melting together D) animals digging holes
explanation: Soil is formed when rocks are broken down by wind, water, and weather over long periods of time. This process is called weathering.

subject: Science
question: What are humans' skeletons made of?
explanation: Humans have an internal skeleton called the skeletal system which is made up of bones. Bones provide structure, protect organs, and help us move.

subject: Science
question: What do magnets always have?
explanation: Magnets always have two poles - a north pole and a south pole. This is a basic property of magnets.

subject: Science
question: What do plants need to grow?

subject: Science
question: What do plants need to grow? A) Water, soil and air B) Sunlight, rocks and food C) Air, heat and money D) Water, light and nutrients
explanation: Plants need water to drink, light (sunshine) to make food, and nutrients from the soil to grow strong. These three things are essential for all plants to survive and grow.

subject: Science
question: What do we call a push or pull acting on an object?
explanation: A push or pull acting on an object is scientifically called a force. Motion is the change in position, energy is the ability to do work, and gravity is a specific type of force that pulls objects toward each other.

subject: Science
question: What do we call a push or pull in science?
explanation: A push or pull is called a force. Forces can make objects move, stop moving, or change direction.

subject: Science
question: What do you see when you hold your hand in front of a lamp?
explanation: When light hits an opaque object, it cannot pass through and creates a dark area behind the object called a shadow. This happens because the object blocks all or part of the light.

subject: Science
question: What helps us move our bones?

subject: Science
question: What is formed when an opaque object blocks light?

subject: Science
question: What is the correct number of poles that all magnets have?
explanation: Magnets always have two poles - a north pole and a south pole. This is a basic property of magnets.

subject: Science
question: What part of a plant grows in the ground and吸水and nutrients from the soil?
explanation: Roots are the part of a plant that grow underground and absorb water and nutrients from the soil. Leaves collect sunlight, stems carry materials between parts, and flowers make seeds.

subject: Science
question: What part of a plant takes in water and nutrients from the soil?

subject: Science
question: Which material will a magnet attract? A) Wood B) Plastic C) Iron D) Copper
explanation: Magnets are attracted to iron and other ferromagnetic materials. Wood, plastic, and copper are not magnetic materials that magnets can attract.

subject: Science
question: Which material will magnets attract? A) Wood B) Plastic C) Iron D) Copper
explanation: Magnets are attracted to iron objects like nails, screws and keys. Wood, plastic and copper are not magnetic materials.

subject: Science
question: Which of these objects will a magnet stick to? A plastic toy B wooden block C iron nail D cotton ball
explanation: Magnets are naturally attracted to iron and steel materials. Plastic, wood, and cotton are not magnetic materials that magnets can attract.

subject: Science
question: Which part of the plant makes food using sunlight?
explanation: Leaves make food through photosynthesis using sunlight, water and carbon dioxide. Roots absorb water and nutrients from soil. Stem transports materials up and down the plant. Flowers are for reproduction.

subject: Science
question: Which part of the plant makes food?

subject: Science
question: Which rock type is formed by cooling lava?

subject: Science
question: Which rock type is formed when lava cools down and becomes solid?
explanation: Igneous rocks are formed when hot lava cools and hardens. Sedimentary rocks form from layers of sediment, and metamorphic rocks change under heat and pressure. Granite is actually a type of igneous rock, but the question asks for the general rock type formed by cooling lava.

subject: Science
question: Which type of rock is made when lava cools down and becomes solid?
explanation: Igneous rocks are formed when hot lava cools and hardens. Sedimentary rocks form from layers of sediment, and metamorphic rocks form when existing rocks are changed by heat and pressure.

subject: Science
question: A complete path for electricity is called:

subject: Science
question: How can living things be grouped together?
explanation: Living things are grouped by their shared characteristics like how they look, what they need to survive, and how they behave. While some animals live in similar places or have similar sizes, these aren't the main ways scientists group living things. Colour is not a reliable way to group them because many different types of living things can be the same colour.

subject: Science
question: How do scientists group living things together?
options: where they live in the world
explanation: Scientists group living things together based on their shared characteristics like having cells, needing water and food, growing, and reproducing. While animals might live in similar places or eat similar foods, these aren't the main ways scientists classify living things.

subject: Science
question: How does sound travel from a speaker to your ears?
correct: waves through the air or other materials
options: tiny invisible particles flying through space
directly from your ears to your brain
as a single continuous stream of energy
explanation: Sound travels as waves that move through air, water, or solid materials. These sound waves cause molecules to vibrate and transfer the sound energy from one place to another.

subject: Science
question: How does sound travel from its source to our ears?
correct: vibrations through air or other materials
options: tiny invisible particles flying through space
sound energy that appears out of nowhere
explanation: Sound travels as vibrations that move through air, water, or solids to reach our ears. These vibrations are created when objects shake or move back and forth.

subject: Science
question: How does sound travel from one place to another?
options: as particles moving in straight lines
explanation: Sound travels as waves that need a medium like air, water or solids to move through. It cannot travel through empty space.

subject: Science
question: How does sound travel through the world around us?
explanation: Sound travels as waves that move through different materials like air, water, and solids. These sound waves can travel in all directions, not just straight lines.

subject: Science
question: How does sound travel to our ears?
correct: vibrations through air or other materials
explanation: Sound travels as vibrations that move through air, water, or solid materials to reach our ears. These vibrations are what we hear when sounds are made.

question: The three main states of matter are:

subject: Science
question: What are the three main states of matter?
explanation: The three main states of matter are solid, liquid, and gas. These describe how matter behaves based on the arrangement and movement of particles.

subject: Science
question: What do we call the complete path that electricity follows in an electric light?
explanation: A circuit is a complete loop that electricity can flow through. A wire carries the electricity, a switch controls the flow, and a battery provides the power, but only together do they make a working circuit.

subject: Science
question: What do we call the complete path that electricity must follow to work correctly in a electrical device?
explanation: A circuit is a complete path that allows electricity to flow from a power source through wires and devices, then back to the power source. Without a complete circuit, electricity cannot flow properly.

subject: Science
question: What state of matter has particles that are close together but can move around and slide past each other?
explanation: Liquids have particles that are close together but not in a fixed position, allowing them to flow and slide past each other. Gases have widely spaced particles that move freely, solids have tightly packed particles that vibrate in fixed positions, and plasma is an electrically charged gas state.

subject: Science
question: When water boils, it becomes:

subject: Science
question: Where does digestion start in the human body?
explanation: Digestion starts in the mouth when you chew food and saliva begins breaking it down. The process continues as food travels through your digestive system.

question: Where does digestion start?

question: Which material conducts electricity?

subject: Science
question: Which of these cannot carry sound waves? Sound cannot travel through:
explanation: Sound needs matter (like air, water or solids) to travel through. In a vacuum (empty space with no particles), there are no molecules for sound waves to vibrate and carry the sound. This is why astronauts communicate via radio in space.

subject: Science
question: Which of these cannot carry sound waves? Sound needs particles to travel through, so it cannot go through:
explanation: Sound needs matter to travel through - it can move through liquids, solids, and gases but not through a vacuum where there are no particles to vibrate.

subject: Science
question: Which of these materials would let electricity pass through it most easily? A) Paper clip B) Glass cup C) Copper wire D) Cotton wool
explanation: Copper is a metal that allows electricity to flow through it easily. Wood, plastic and rubber are insulators that do not conduct electricity well.

subject: Science
question: Which of these materials would let electricity pass through it? A wooden table B plastic bottle C copper wire D rubber boot
explanation: Copper is a metal that allows electric current to flow through it easily. Wood, plastic, and rubber are insulators that block electricity from flowing.

subject: Science
question: Which of these materials would let electricity pass through it? Copper wire, wooden table, plastic bottle, or rubber boot?
explanation: Copper is a metal that allows electricity to flow through it easily. Wood, plastic, and rubber are insulators that block electricity flow.

subject: Science
question: Which state of matter has particles that are close together but can slide past each other?
explanation: Liquids have particles that are close together but not in a fixed pattern, allowing them to flow and slide past each other. Gases have widely spaced particles that move freely, solids have tightly packed particles that vibrate in place, and plasma is an electrically charged gas state.

subject: Science
question: Which state of matter has particles that are closely packed but can slide past each other?
explanation: Liquids have particles that are close together but not in a fixed pattern, allowing them to flow and slide past each other. Gases have widely spaced particles that move freely, solids have tightly packed particles in a fixed shape, and plasma is an ionized gas state.

subject: Science
question: Which teeth are for cutting?

subject: Science
question: Which teeth are used for cutting food?
explanation: Incisors are the flat, sharp teeth at the front of your mouth that are designed for cutting and biting food.

subject: Science
question: Which type of tooth is used for cutting food?
explanation: Incisors are the flat, sharp teeth at the front of your mouth that are used for cutting and biting food into smaller pieces.

question: How long does it take for the Earth to spin around once?
explanation: The Earth takes 24 hours to rotate once on its axis, which is why we have day and night. This rotation happens at a steady pace that gives us our 24-hour day cycle.

question: The life cycle of a mammal includes:

subject: Science
question: What are the main stages in the life cycle of a mammal like a dog or cat?
explanation: Mammals go through birth, growing up, reproducing, and eventually dying. Insects and plants have different life cycles, such as metamorphosis or growing from seeds.

subject: Science
question: What does the Earth orbit around in space?
explanation: The Earth orbits around the Sun in our solar system. The Moon orbits around Earth, not the other way round.

subject: Science
question: What is the name of the force that pulls objects towards the Earth?
explanation: Gravity is the invisible force that pulls all objects towards the centre of the Earth. This is why things fall down when you drop them and why we stay on the ground.

subject: Science
question: When wood burns, it changes into different substances like ash and smoke. What type of change is this?
explanation: Burning wood is a chemical change because it creates new substances (ash, smoke, gases) that cannot be changed back into wood. The wood reacts with oxygen in the air to form completely different materials.

subject: Science
question: When wood burns, it creates new materials that can't be changed back into wood again. What type of change is this?
explanation: Burning wood is a chemical change because the wood reacts with oxygen to create new substances like ash, smoke and heat. The original wood cannot be recovered from these products.

subject: Science
question: Which list shows the stages in a mammal's life cycle?
options: larva, pupa, fully grown insect, egg
explanation: Mammals are born, grow into young animals, become fully grown, and eventually raise their own young. Other cycles belong to plants or insects.

subject: Science
question: Which of these describes a change that cannot be reversed?
correct: A change that cannot be reversed is a permanent change
options: A change that can be reversed is a temporary change
A change that happens quickly is a fast change
A change that uses heat is a heating change
explanation: A permanent change (or irreversible change) is when materials are changed and cannot be returned to their original form. Examples include burning paper or cooking an egg.

subject: Science
question: Which of these is an example of a change that cannot be reversed?
explanation: Burning paper to ash is a permanent chemical change that cannot be reversed. Melting ice, dissolving sugar, and breaking glass are all physical changes that can be reversed.

subject: Science
question: Which of these shows the correct life cycle of a mammal like a dog or cat?
explanation: Mammals are born, grow, reproduce, and eventually die. Insects often go through metamorphosis and plants follow stages like sprouting and flowering.

question: 1. Before wrapping a body in bandages, the body was embalmed to help preserve it. Special priests called embalmers, having first washed the body in palm oil, removed all of the organs through a cut in the left hand side of the body. The job was very skilful, demanding that the Embalmers perform the correct rituals and say prayers throughout the process, as well as understand the anatomy of the human body. The brain was broken up and pulled out through the nasal passages using a copper hook. The heart was the only organ that was left in the body due to the Egyptian belief that it was the organ of reasoning.
correct: The four canopic jars were used to hold the removed organs
options: The four canopic jars were used to store the mummy's clothing
The four canopic jars were used as containers for the mummy's food offerings
The four canopic jars were used to hold the preserved brain

question: Markus Persson Markus Persson, better known as Notch, is the creator of the video game Minecraft. He was born in the 1st of June 1979 in Stockholm, Sweden. Until he was seven, he lived in a small town called Edsbyn. The town is surrounded by forests and he spent a lot of time walking in the trees. He also enjoyed playing with Lego, which he used to make complex designs. His father brought him a computer when he was seven. Markus loved it and wrote his first computer program when he was eight. Persson did not finish High School. He studied an online computer programming course, and he was able to get a job working with computers.

question: Mummification in Ancient Egypt The ancient Egyptians believed in life after death. They also believed that it was important to preserve the bodies of the dead. Bodies were wrapped in bandages to stop them rotting. We now call these bodies ‘mummies’. How did the Egyptians preserve the bodies of the dead?
correct: They wrapped the bodies in bandages and used special chemicals to dry them out
options: They buried them in the sand
They cooked them in hot ovens
They painted them with special paint
